turn.text: Well, lien had accrued, I am talking --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If it hadn't the government could easily have perfected it.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Yes I think that's true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: With respect to any of the assets of the corporation?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: I assume that's true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that was in position to tell the company -- tell the company and I know if you are as money comes in you pay it over because we have a lien on these things you have got.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Yes, but exercising (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: -- prefer to see the corporation --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All I am saying is -- all I am saying is they can protect themselves.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Well they could protect themselves.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: First 1770000, they could get if they wanted to.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And they could take some risk.
So they could say well we make get more if we got him go ahead and you say that's what they really do.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Well, yes that's what they do in practice or what they apparently did here, but they made no agreement here it is not asserted here that they made any agreement that they would not -- that they would absolve the petitioner of the liability for this if the petitioner --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They certainly if they had lien or could it had it they certainly didn't assert it with respect to certain moneys.
They said go pay your bills, don't give it us although we have a lien on it, go pay somebody else.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Well, that's.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now you are saying well that money they paid out the risk didn't turn out and we are going to collect it from the man himself.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Well that's right and that's what Congress had in mind here, because otherwise there would be.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's a question -- the question is whether that's one thing had in mind or not?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: And that the fact that the government takes a risk in a situation like this doesn't mean that 6672 liability doesn't not apply --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course in your view the government really isn't taking a risk, because if the corporation succeeds, it gets it from the corporation and if the corporation fails it gets it from the person --

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: There is no reason to think that it can't get it from the person in charge after all.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If the person in charge doesn't have it then it's only to that extent --

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Yes and one might well assume that the government would have a better chance to get it from those first bills that came into the corporation and from the individual.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, can't you concede that it shouldn't be interpreted that failure to pay over it's a government says you'll go ahead we are waving around lien pay it to somebody else.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: The government did not, he doesn't claim to the government made any such express agreement here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose it did?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: I think that will be different case if it were claimed that the government had.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I call up the government -- they call at the government on the telephone, the government on the telephone, the IRS says here is our situation and the government says we got a lien on a every dollar you get.
Well, alright and then they talk for a while, the government says, well, we probably going to get along better if we rock along, we might get all of our money sooner or later.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: Without that's simply is not claimed to be the fact here Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If it were what would you say?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Deputy Solicitor General Barnett
turn.text: I think that will be an interesting case in the estoppel of government and well the government can be equitably estopped.
Thank you my time is up.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have nay thing further Mr. Kleinman?

turn.speaker: bennet_kleinman
turn.label: Mr. Bennet Kleinman
turn.text: If the Court please, in terms of analysis of the Section the individual petitioner or the party being charge its charge with such tax.
Such tax is the tax required to be collected by him.
As Mr. Justice Stevens said, if it were not that tax then the individual could be held liable for corporate income taxes and every other tax along the board if such tax only meant any tax.
It means such tax means any tax required to be collected by him.
If in fact what the government says is true it doesn't make any difference, when the tax accrued.
We are talking about tax for particular period, not just any old withholding taxes.

If in fact what the government says is true then a man could today become a responsible officer, pay every dollar he owned, leave the company, the next people did not pay the withholding taxes and he could be held responsible under the government's interpretation, because one time he was a responsible officer.

They said that all three of those things did converge when he become the responsible officer, but that doesn't mean he is only responsible for the period of time when they converged, but for the period of time before, well if before why not after and I suggest you that this is not what was intended.
The fact of the matter is that in this case when the government knew that the tax was not paid, Mr. Dr. Slodov went to them paid the tax because he was advised that funds were available to pay.
So he decided that if the funds were available he would pay.
When he find.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The funds were available because they had withheld them from the employees.

turn.speaker: bennet_kleinman
turn.label: Mr. Bennet Kleinman
turn.text: But they no they were to be in the bank.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, no, but after he came on he continue to withhold.

turn.speaker: bennet_kleinman
turn.label: Mr. Bennet Kleinman
turn.text: I am not talking about that withholding.

When he brought the company he knew that there was a withholding tax liability of the company, but he had been advised by the seller of the stock to him that the money was in the bank all you got to do is go in and pay, it is due tomorrow, you are going to write the checks and pay the money, he went in and the money wasn't there.
Now this could -- this is such a dangerous thing to anyone purchasing stock.

It would seem that whether he knew of the tax or not or whether he made an investigation, he could of have had the accountants in there for months and not known that the government would come in at later date and say that these people whom you employee and whom you can and who you contend are independent contractors and therefore you don't withhold or in fact employees and you should have withheld and if he did not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I think you opponent would answer you before and after cases well as this one by emphasizing the word willfully in the statute.

turn.speaker: bennet_kleinman
turn.label: Mr. Bennet Kleinman
turn.text: Well, willfully he could have paid it, he could have paid the money.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But on your after situation we didn't know what happen later it could be willfully.

turn.speaker: bennet_kleinman
turn.label: Mr. Bennet Kleinman
turn.text: Now but the willful point is if you knew the tax was liable.
